summary: This document is a chain of internal FBI emails from September 2019 discussing victim services and compensation for victims of Jeffrey Epstein. The emails show FBI personnel in New York and the Victim Services Division coordinating to determine if victims who recently disclosed abuse can still apply for compensation, with a reference to needing a letter from a prosecutor.

connections.description: M., an FBI Victim Specialist, emails S., the Executive Director of OVS, to inquire about victim compensation applications, and S. responds with guidance.

events.title: OVS Inquiry about Epstein Victim Compensation
events.description: An FBI Victim Specialist (M.) emails the Executive Director of OVS (S.) to ask if Epstein victims who recently disclosed abuse can still apply for compensation through OVS.

events.title: FBI Internal Forwarding of Victim Request
events.description: FBI emails are forwarded internally regarding the victim compensation inquiry, with a request to push it to SDNY (Southern District of New York).

events.title: Follow-up on Epstein Victim Services
events.description: FBI personnel follow up on the earlier inquiry about victim services and compensation for Epstein victims, seeking a quick update.

keyFacts: FBI Victim Specialists were actively working with multiple Epstein victims in the New York City area who had recently disclosed their abuse years after it occurred.

The Office for Victims of Crime (OVS) indicated compensation might be possible if a letter from a District Attorney or Assistant U.S. Attorney stated they would have prosecuted the case if it had been brought in a timely manner.
The email chain shows internal FBI coordination between New York field office personnel and the FBI Victim Services Division regarding victim support following Epstein's death in August 2019.
The correspondence references pushing the victim services request to the Southern District of New York (SDNY) for action.
